{{Infobox musical artist | name = Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Kenneth Wayne Spruell | alias = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|mf=y|1944}}
[[Spokane, Washington]], United States | death_date = | origin = | instrument = [[Piano]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Blues]], [[boogie-woogie]], [[jazz]] | occupation = Musician, pianist, singer, songwriter | years_active = 1962–present | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|http://www.kennybluesboss.com/|Official website}} | notable_instruments = }} '''Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne''' (born '''Kenneth Wayne Spruell''',{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hotburrito.nl/ency/blues/kennywayne.html |title=Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne at Hotburrito's Bluesencyclopedia |publisher=Hotburrito.nl |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} 1944, [[Spokane, Washington]]) is an American [[blues]], [[boogie-woogie]] and [[jazz]] [[pianist]], singer and songwriter. [[Music journalism|Music journalist]], Jeff Johnson, writing in the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' stated, "There's no boogie-woogie-blues piano man out there today who pounds the 88's with the conviction of Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne." ==Biography== Wayne was born in Spokane, but he relocated with his family to San Francisco, California at an early age.{{cite web|author=Linda Seida |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/kenny-blues-boss-wayne-mn0000598239/biography |title=Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} His parents alternatively advised for and against the blues, but his mother's influence led Wayne to be influenced early by [[Nat King Cole]], [[Little Willie John]], and [[Fats Domino]]. The family moved in turn to [[New Orleans]], Los Angeles and [[Compton, California]].[http://www.reginablues.ca/mp3s_festival/Kenny_Blues_Boss_Wayne/Kenny_Blues_Boss_Wayne.htm ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}} While he was growing up, Wayne drew further inspiration from [[The Three Sounds]], [[George Shearing]], [[Erroll Garner]], [[Cal Tjader]], [[Mongo Santamaría]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Charles Brown (musician)|Charles Brown]], [[Floyd Dixon]], [[Big Joe Turner]], and [[Jimmy Reed]]. Based in Los Angeles during the 1960s and 1970s, Wayne was utilised as a [[sideman]] by various [[pop music|pop]] and [[rock music|rock]] musicians. In the 1980s Wayne relocated again to [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. "Blues Boss" (his nickname was acquired from the title of [[Amos Milburn]]'s comeback album with [[Motown Records]]) undertook a tour of Europe in 1994. Wayne dedicated his debut album to his parents, and 2002 heralded the issue of ''88th & Jump Street'', followed by ''Blues Carry Me Home'' (2003) and ''Let It Loose'' (2005). His [[music festival|festival]] appearances have included [[Edmonton's Labatt Blues Festival]] (2004) and [[Koktebel Jazz Festival]] (2006). In May 2008, Wayne issued his album, ''Can't Stop Now''.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/cant-stop-now-mw0000785054 |title=Can't Stop Now - Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2008-05-20 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} Wayne's most recent release, ''Rollin' with the Blues Boss'' (2014), included guest contributions from [[Diunna Greenleaf]] and [[Eric Bibb]].{{cite web|author=Steve Leggett |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/rollin-with-the-blues-boss-mw0002629844 |title=Rollin' with the Blues Boss - Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2014-04-22 |accessdate=2014-05-16}} ==Juno Awards== Nominated in [[Juno Awards of 1997|1997]] for 'Best Blues/Gospel Album,' and in [[Juno Awards of 1999|1999]] and [[Juno Awards of 2003|2003]] for 'Best Blues Album,' Wayne was presented with a [[Juno Award for Blues Album of the Year|Juno Award]] in [[Juno Awards of 2006|2006]] for ''Let It Loose''. ==Discography== ===Solo=== *''Blues Boss Boogie'' (1999) - Real Blues *''88th & Jump Street'' (2002) - Electro-Fi *''Blues Carry Me Home'' (2003) - Isabel *''Let It Loose'' (2005) - Electro Fi *''Alive & Loose'' (2006) - Blue Roots *''Can't Stop Now'' (2008) - Electro-Fi *''An Old Rock on a Roll'' (2011) - Stony Plain *''Rollin' with the Blues Boss'' (2014) - Stony Plain{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/kenny-blues-boss-wayne-mn0000598239/discography |title=Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} ===Compilation inclusions=== *''[[Saturday Night Blues: 20 Years]]'' (2006) - [[CBC Radio|CBC]]A [[compilation album]] of live performances from the [[Saturday Night Blues]] radio program on [[CBC Radio]], hosted by [[Holger Petersen]]. Wayne's "Blackberry Wine", originally recorded for ''Let It Loose'', is included. ==See also== *[[List of boogie woogie musicians]] *[[List of people from Spokane, Washington]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.kennybluesboss.com/ Official website] {{Authority control|VIAF=106110347}} {{Persondata | NAME = Wayne, Kenny Blues Boss | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Spruell, Kenneth Wayne | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[blues]], [[boogie-woogie]] and [[jazz]] pianist, singer and songwriter | DATE OF BIRTH = 1944 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Spokane, Washington]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wayne, Kenny Blues Boss}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues pianists]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American jazz pianists]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Washington (state)]] [[Category:Boogie-woogie pianists]] [[Category:People from Spokane, Washington]] [[Category:Juno Award winners]]
